title: Application submitted for new Inverness river artwork
story: Aplanning application has been submitted for the new public artwork, entitled lsquoMy Nessrsquo to be situated at the Little Isle Pool, Fishermanrsquos Car Park by the River Ness.The new concept for the ldquoGathering Place, which is the centrepiece of the River Ness Art Project, was launched earlier this year.Last autumn the artists Sans Faccedilon and OSA set up a large screen in Inverness Railway Station to show a specially commissioned film of the river and invited people to come and share their stories, views and reminiscences to inspire the eventual design.The pound, feature is funded by Creative Scotland , Inverness Common Good Fund , Highland Counciland Highlands and Islands Enterprise .Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Artful end to Inverness housing project
story: Artwork by pupils from Merkinch Primary School has provided the finishing touches to a new homes project in Inverness.P and P pupils drew images of iconic city landmarks which have now been etched onto a footpath from the new homes to a play area and the school.The project to create  homes for affordable rent, mid-market rent and low cost ownership at Merkinch Place is a partnership between Highland Council, the Highland Housing Alliance , the Scottish Government and the City-Region Deal.With families now moving in depute provost and local ward councillor Bet McAllister said: ldquoThis represents a huge investment into the local community and Irsquom delighted that families are now moving in and will be able to enjoy Christmas in their new homes. Having the artwork produced by the pupils incorporated is a fantastic idea and I thank them all for their creative input for this project.Gail Matheson, chief executive of Highland Housing Alliance, said: ldquoIt has been amazing to see the new homes built on the area and we have been impressed with the design of the homes and the streetscape. The paving designed by the pupils really finishes it off.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Caledonian Canal hub awaits the green light
story: PREPARATIONS are under way in anticipation of work starting on an ambitious regeneration project next to the Caledonian Canal in Inverness ndash although planning permission is yet to be granted.Scottish Canals has a long-held aim to develop an outdoor hub and cafeacute on a derelict site off Carsegate Road, Merkinch. It will also provide Inverness Sea Scouts with a new base to replace their decaying building.The project was awarded pound, this year by the Scottish Governmentrsquos regeneration capital grant fund which supports community projects in disadvantaged and rural areas.Following consultation with local residents and organisations, it has now submitted a planning application to Highland Council for an office multi-purpose building and boat usersrsquo store plus a cafe linked by a foot bridge.But Inverness boating enthusiast David Edes has objected to the plans in their present form and is querying why work appears to have started.He is concerned about vehicular access for construction and deliveries, maintaining the current track behind canalside offices is unsuitable while the junction coming on to the A is dficult.ldquoAny increase in traffic using this junction needs to be avoided, he stated.ldquoHaving cars towing m canoe trailers through here is an accident waiting to happen.He is also concerned about car parking spaces and potential for noise from the centre which will be next to residential berths.ldquoThe centre should never be licensed to sell alcohol in the interests of the residential amenity and on the grounds of safety as itrsquos so close to the water, he said.Mr Edes would support the plansthe concerns were addressed especially as the sea scouts needed modern fit-for-purpose premises.A spokesman for Scottish Canals insisted work had not started. He said scrub clearance had been carried out to enable safe access for site investigations which did not require planning consent.A full ecology and tree survey was undertaken ahead of the clearance.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Dolphins delight in the firth
story: Bottlenose dolphin Kesslet and her baby daughter, who was born on September , have been a regular sight recently in both the Beauly Firth as well as the Kessock Channel.Mr Phillips said: ldquoI know the exact date and almost to the hour time of birth thanks to my friends at the wildle tour company Dolphin Spirit that cruises in and out of Inverness Harbour during the season.ldquoThey let me know right away that they had spotted Kesslet with a tiny newborn beside her.ldquoThis is Kessletrsquos fourth offspring. Her oldest, a young male called Charlie, is  years old and a very regular visitor to the Kessock Channel.ldquoKesslet has had two more recent babies that have sadly not survived, but Irsquom hoping that this beautul little girl will survive and thrive to thrill the locals and visitors to the area for many years to come.Kesslet is one of the dolphins that the public can ldquoadopt through Whale and Dolphin Conservation, with more details available at http:uk.whales.org adoptions dolphinsWednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Festive cheer for vulnerable at Inverness and Nairn churches
story: A NUMBER of events are being held across the Highlands to help prevent loneliness and isolation on Christmas Day.Rev Sarah Murray and staff at Inverness Cathedral is hosting an open table Christmas lunch in the Old Boysrsquo School from -pm.Entry is free and is open to all to help provide comfort to those who are alone or find the festive period dficult.Ness Bank Church is also hosting its annual festive lunch from .pm.The three-course meal, with all the trimmings, is being served up for the sixth year in succession.Anyone interested should call   or attend on the day.Nairn United Reformed Church is also hosting a meal at .pm for the disadvantaged and those who may be on their own.Those interested should contact Angela on quinnie@btopenworld.Inverness Caledonian Thistle FC is holding an event for elderly people who may be on their own.The club is laying on a meal and showing a Christmas film.Anyone wanting to attend should call Pauline   to book places and arrange transport.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Health chief at audit hearing
story: NHS Highlandrsquos outgoing chief executive gave evidence at the Scottish Parliamentrsquos public audit and post-legislative scrutiny committee.Elaine Mead was called to discuss financial sustainability as the board is under scrutiny because pound million of brokerage was needed to break even despite making ldquounprecedented savings of pound million.In recent month NHS Highland has been criticised over bullying and financial mismanagement allegations.MSP Edward Mountain vowed to ldquopress the Scottish Government and the senior executive management of NHS Highland for the improvements our patients need and deserve.A NHS Highland spokesman said: ldquoNHS Highland would like to thank the public audit and post-legislative scrutiny committee for the opportunity to highlight the issues of sustainability across our board area and indeed NHS Scotland.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Highland building firm helps food bank
story: Staff from Morrison Construction have been volunteering to work at Highland Foodbankrsquos warehouse in Inverness.They helped sort out the hundreds of food donations, getting boxes ready for distribution to those who need help the most.The volunteer work was part of Morrison Constructionrsquos company-wide initiative encouraging staff to take the time from their work schedule to help support a local charity or community group.Lorna Dempster, co-ordinator at Highland Foodbank, said: ldquoWe really enjoy working with the volunteers from Morrison Construction. There are so many things that need to be done in the run up to Christmas and wersquore grateful for everyone that gets involved. There are always things that need doing throughout the year. January is a great opportunity for thinking of doing something new.Sally Cooper, at Morrison Construction, said: ldquoOur staff have been great at coming forward to help local good causes and Highland Foodbank is certainly one of those. We understand the struggles of additional costs associated with making Christmas special for families. Our staff regularly donate food items to our food bank collection box and this is a good way of giving a helping hand towards making Christmas easier for these families.Last Saturday, the Inverness Culloden Rotary Club collected almost a tonne of food at Morrisonrsquos Supermarket for donation to the Highland Foodbank for distribution.A large number of people contributed to the food collection including Ryan Williams who has become known locally as ldquothe opera guy who donated a large trolley full of food. Rotarian Duncan MacDonald said: ldquoHe sings on High Street on many occasions and his contribution was hugely generous.Food bank organisers warn of a further spike of need in the New Year as cash-strapped families run out of food after the festive period.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Highland holiday home aims to boost charity
story: A HOLIDAY home business has pledged to donate more than pound to charitya luxury island property is booked for Hogmanay.Little and Large Holiday Houses , a self-catering holiday home rental agency, will hand over pound to the Highland HospiceOran na Mara on Harris is filled for New Year.Holding up to six people, it is vacant from December  to January  and is being offered for half of its regular price at pound following a cancellation.Half of the fee will be matched by the agent and will go to the hospice.LHH owner Wynne Shilland is behind the idea. After the loss of her husband to cancer in , Mrs Shilland started volunteering at the hospice every Wednesday offering massage therapy and LHH has also given stays at holiday homes as prizes for hospice raffles in the past.Mrs Shilland said: ldquoAs itrsquos a charity, it has to fund itself.Paul Honeywell, the owner of the Oran na Mara, was planning on staying in the home with his family for the new year however after a last minute change of plans decided to stay at home.ldquoI donrsquot get up there myself enough, he said.ldquoItrsquos a very unique part of the world. What a wonderful way to celebrate the New Year ndash therersquos even a chance of seeing the Northern Lights.ldquoYou can have bracing walks on the beach, and evenitrsquos wet and wild outside you can sit back in comfort, put the fire on and watch it all happen around you through the windows.Apart from the availability over the New Year the property is fully booked until .Hospice fundraising manager Amanda Burt said: ldquoWe are so grateful for this very generous donation.ldquoThe holiday home looks stunning, and itrsquos great that people can enjoy a lovely break in the New Year while supporting the hospice.The property is still available, despite several inquiries.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Inverness Airport lands extra Dutch flights
story: A THIRD daily flight between Inverness and Amsterdam is to launch next summer, giving Inverness even more access to dream destinations worldwide.The move by airline KLM has been welcomed by local business leaders as a major boost for the city.The new flights will fly Monday to Saturday during the peak summer period of June and July thanks to the success of the current route including a rise in numbers wishing to use the Amsterdam hub for onward travel instead of Heathrow or Luton.Last year KLM boosted Inverness-Amsterdam flights to two per day and then announced bigger planes would be used on the route, with the summer service using a Boeing .The additional flights are earmarked to run from July  to August  initially, but could become a permanent featurethey prove popular. The additional flight will use a B aircraft, carrying  passengers.Hial managing director Inglis Lyon said: ldquoWe have been delighted at the success of the Inverness-Amsterdam flights and for KLM to now offer three flights a day is tremendous, given the connection was launched little more than two years ago.ldquoThe extra flight will make a huge dference to passengers. Travellers will have more options for onward connections.Inverness Airport general manager Graeme Bell said: "The route has always been very popular with European travellers. In addition the long-haul market is hugely important and connecting through Amsterdam opens up these international destinations, allowing people to travel to and from Inverness on one ticket. This is a real vote of confidence in Inverness Airport."General manager for Air France-KLM UK, Benedicte Duval, said: "The enhanced schedule will provide the local Highland community with more choice and even better connection times during what is the key holiday season. The additional flight adds  per cent more seats when compared with the same period last year, making this beautul region more accessible for international tourists."Stewart Nicol, chief executive of Inverness Chamber of Commerce, called the announcement "fantastic" and added: "It is a real endorsement of what the route has been doing for KLM and an indication of how hard the guys at Inverness Airport have been working with the airlines to develop routes."Regarding the possibility of the third flight becoming permanent he added: "The pattern in the past with a number of airlines is to test the market like this, and in the past it has led on to the development of actual routes that have been to the benefit of Inverness and the region."Graeme Ambrose, chief executive of the VisitInvernessLochNess business improvement district said: "This is just another great bonus, more good news in terms of what Inverness Airport has been achieving over the past few months with other flights to the north. They are on a roll."Inverness economist Tony Mackay said he hoped Brexit would not prove a stumbling block."There has been a big increase in European visitor numbers to Inverness and the Highlands because of the fall in the value of the pound after the Brexit vote," he said. "KLM have obviously benefited from that. I also believe that many business passengers to or from overseas prefer to fly via Amsterdam rather than Heathrow or Luton."One note of caution, however, is the possible adverse impact of Brexit once it takes effect. That could reduce passenger numbers in the future."n People travelling between Inverness and London were faced with travel chaos yesterday after all flights to and from Gatwick Airport were suspended.Services were cancelled and delayed due to drones being flown close to the site.Among those affected were the .am and .pm flights from the capital to the Highlands.A statement from Gatwick Airport said: "We apologise to all of our passengers who are impacted, but the safety of our passengers and all staff is our priority."Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Ness Islands art project is approved
story: A PIECE of artwork doubling up as a childrenrsquos water play area is set to go ahead after planning permission was granted.The pound, installation at Ness Islands will consist of patterned stepping stones made of granite which sit in a stainless steel channel fed by water from the river.Some of the stones will be fitted with moveable sluice gates to allow children to control the flow of water themselves.The development forms one part of the River Ness Public Art Project, which is worth a total of pound,.Throughout the design of the project, local schoolchildren were consulted on what they would like to see installed, while students from Inverness College UHI were also involved.Highland Councilrsquos city centre manager David Haas welcomed the news that the project had been given the green light and believes it will showcase the best of Inverness to locals and visitors alike.ldquoItrsquos further investment in the city and itrsquos going to be a very special facility for families to enjoy, he said.ldquoItrsquos another reason for people to visit our wonderful islands.ldquoIt will enable more people to spend more time on the islands and appreciate a beautul part of the city.ldquoWe are very pleased with the work that has been produced.The installation is close to the proposed site of My Ness, for which a planning application has now been submitted.Described as a ldquogathering place, the pound, feature would form the centrepiece of the public art project.It consists of a partial, circular amphitheatre with elements on both banks in order to ldquoframe the river, and also contains a walkway, seating area and viewing point.It was designed in collaboration with anglers, who use the area on a regular basis.Mr Haas believes the project will allow people to connect with their surroundings.ldquoThe most important thing is that all the projects raise the profile of our city and bring the community closer to everything the area has to offer, he said.ldquoIt will make people realise what a wonderful place we live in.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Things are hotting up for Hogmanay in Inverness
story: These include the Travelodge as well as the Palace Hotel and the Mercure in the city centre, along with the Craigmonie and Crown Court Hotels in the Crown area and those further afield such as Bunchrew House Hotel by the Beauly Firth.Bunchrew House reported it was not unusual to have ldquono room at the inn, with the hotel full most days during what it described as a ldquobumper year. The Royal Highland Hotel on Academy Street is also at full capacity and while many hotels, including the Kingsmills Hotel, are hosting their own Hogmanay events one member of staff at the Royal Highland suggested the annual Red Hot Highland Fling ndash the free Hogmanay event staged by Highland Council at the Northern Meeting ndash is also a major draw for visitors.For the first year those wanting an official souvenir of the fling, which regularly draws thousands of revellers to the city, can get their hands on branded merchandise.The party was named by theas one of the top six UK street parties to attend this year ndash the only Scottish event to make the list ndash and merchandise including T-shirts, hoodies, beanies and bobble hats are all available at Ginger Fashion Accessories in the cityrsquos Victorian Market as well as online at www.invernesseventsshopIt is hoped the revenue will help offset some of the costs of staging city events which have an annual budget of about pound,.The family-friendly fling alone ndash which is unticketed ndash costs about pound, to put on every year.Gerry Reynolds, the councilrsquos events manager, said: ldquoA lot of people have said they would like to help, so this is a way of making a contribution.ldquoPeople have often askedthere any souvenirs ndash people do like to collect souvenirs and the Red Hot Highland Fling for some people is a once-in-a-letime experience.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: gaffer del confident lowe ship has sailedfor dons
story: Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes admits he would be delightedDerby County do an unexpected U-turn and sanction theof left-back Max Lowe to Pittodrie.However, McInnes is not going to sit by the phone hoping for a call from Derby and will instead hunt for a replacement left-back in the January transfer window.Lowe was outstanding during a half-season loan and has now ed to Pride Park after that loan expired.McInnes wanted to extend Lowe’s time at Pittodrie until the end of the season but was informed by Rams boss Frank Lampard the defender wouldto his parent club due to a left-back injury crisis.Such was the impact of Lowe in his four months at the Dons that McInnes aims to secure a left-back with similar qualities who, as well as being defensively Granite solid, can also rampage down the wing and deliver dangerous crosses into the box.In an ideal world that position would be filled by Lowe, but that is unlikely unless Lampard moves to sign a left-back in January or the injuries to key players in that position diminish.The indication from Lampard is that Lowe is not ing to Derby to warm the bench, he will be there to play from the start.As far as hopes of securing Lowe again, McInnes admits “that ship has sailed”.With that in mind and the January transfer window now open McInnes will move to source a left-back this month.However,that call does come from Derby, problem solved.McInnes said: “There is an indication Max is going back to play.Malone is now injured as well,Forsyth is out for the season andOlsson is coming back from a cruciate.“It is pretty clear having spoken to Frank. If I got a phone call to say that has changed I would be over the moon. But I don’t think we can sit back hoping for the phone to ring.“We have just got to be as active as we can to bring in another left-back.“Max would be my first choice to come back because he was magnicent for us. He was such a good kid to work with, but I think that ship has sailed unfortunately. Max is now trying to get himself into Derby’s team.”Left-back is unlikely to be the only position McInnes will move to strengthen this month.McInnes has admitted he would like to add “one or two” signings in the January window ahead of the second half of a campaign where Aberdeen sit just three points behind Premiership leaders Celtic and Rangers.Following the injury to Bruce Anderson in the - defeat of Livingston the Dons gaffer has admitted he could be forced to move for a striker in the window.Lowe is currently out injured having suffered a groin strain in the - defeat of Hearts. He pulled up in the Pittodrie clash and was taken off and missed games against Celticand Livingston .The injury to Lowe is a yet another blow for Derby boss Lampard, with left-back Scott Malone recently sustaining a groin injury that could rule him out for up to six weeks.Derby have not had much luck with left-backs this season as Scotland cap Craig Forsyth is recovering from knee surgery and is out for the campaign.Swedish international left-back Marcus Olsson has not played since the end of last season due to a knee injury. Olsson couldthis month, but he will need time to build match fitness and sharpness.Calum Macdonald, Derby’s left-back in the under-s, is injured.Right-back Andre Wisdom has played on the left recently.Such is the high regard Lampard holds for Lowe, who started the first two Championship games of this season, he tied him up on a new three-year contract less than  hours before he moved on loan to Aberdeen at the end of the summer window.Lampard hopes Lowe will be available within two weeks.Lampard said: “Max has a small groin injury. Hopefully, we are talking minimal weeks as opposed to weeks and weeks.”

title: 1bn target set by tourism chief
story: Aberdeen#s tourism chief has insisted plans to make tourism a £ billion-a-year regional industry by  are “plausible”.VisitAberdeenshire chief executive Chris Foy said ato growth in the business sector along with an increase in the city hosting conferences and events would help the industry achieve the ambitious target.Mr Foy said this will be aided by the opening of a “world class” new exhibition centre – The Event Complex Aberdeen– which is due to open in the summer.He said: “It’s plausible. From that baseline of £ million we’ve already seen quite a big leap in .“We saw a leap to £m.“That was fuelled by a huge growth in day visits but that £bn figure will come from a number of dferent sources.“Part of it will be ato growth in the corporate sector, so that’s part of the predictions, but also more and more growth from hosting conferences and events, the highest spending types of visitors, and then just organic growth in leisure visitors.”He said tourism has the opportunity to grow in an “unprecedented way” with new infrastructure such as TECA underlying that.He said: “We have never had world-class conferencing events in the city of the scale that we’re about to have.“It is the single biggest investment in the UK of something of that scale.”The plan, which was launched in September, aims to make tourism a £bn-a-year regional industry by  with business events, cruise ships, golf, food and drink, culture and outdoor activities identied as six key growth areas.Mr Foy added: “Within our business plan we are taking a direct line of sight from those strengths and building our campaigns around those themes.”VisitAberdeenshire has created a new data dashboard, which brings together around  dferent data sources that are analysed for the benefit of local businesses so they can make decisions on where to spend their money.

story: Adorable animals in Aberdeen are waiting for their new homes.Dogs and cats at Mrs Murray’s Cat and Dog Home in Seaton are dressed up in their finest festive attire in the hopes of winning the hearts of north-east residents looking for a pet for the new year.More than , animals pass through the centre each year looking for a new home.Rehoming of animals has currently stopped, but Mrs Murray’s will open its doors again on January . vw, px"  Gorgeous Staffy Gucci is looking for a nice quiet home she can spend her retirement in and play with her toys. title: first buses to start using aberdeen bypass in weeks
story: Two new bus services are due to start using the Aberdeen bypass this month.Stagecoach has announced that the  and  buses will make use of the AWPR from January , following the opening of most of the route. vw, px"  The project, which is expected to cost more than £ billion when it is finally complete, opened two other legs last month, leaving just the Don River crossing, which was discovered to have internal faults, lagging behind.The  service will serve communities in Angus and Aberdeenshire, travelling hourly from Montrose to Stonehaven, then the Kingswells Park and Ride and Aberdeen International Airport.The  will take in Portlethen and Newtonhill, as well as the airport and the Kingswells Park and Ride.A consultation was held with residents to decide the outline of the , with passengers asking for a direct link to the airport.David Liston, managing director of Stagecoach North Scotland, said: “We are delighted to be able to start the new year by introducing two new services to our Aberdeenshire network.“In our autumn timetable consultation we received a lot of support for the new service  providing a direct bus connection to the airport.“On reviewing consultation feedback from residents in Newtonhill and Portlethen, we have been able to identy a solution that means these communities will also be connected to the airport from January .“We look forward to welcoming both old and new customers on board our new services later this month.”

title: north east towns new market helps boost fish landings by 25
story: A new state-of-the art multi-million-pound fish market has already seen a % increase in fish landings in the last six months.The North Bay market in Peterhead was officially opened by the Duke of Rothesay in September.Since coming into operation in June the market has been setting new records every single week.The new facility, part of the £ million project to redevelop the harbour, replaced the former market on Merchants Quay.The market has the latest refrigeration technology and capacity for , boxes of fish at a time.In the first nine weeks of its operation, more than , boxes of fish were sold in the new market, rising to just short of , boxes in the first  weeks. vw, px"  Chief executive Simon Brebner said they were delighted with the progress of the new facility.He said: “We closed the old fish market on June  and had a pretty seamless transition into the new market.“In the last six months we’ve seen a % rise in the fish landings in the fish market.“With the larger capacity and it being more accessible we are finding the whole sector including the fishermen, processors and transport are happy with the new market.”More than  guests – including royalty – were invited to the opening in September.Simon added: “It was fantastic to get the royal seal of approval from HRH Prince Charles at the opening.“Everyone in the industry has really embraced the new fish market. Everyone who walks into the new market, even royalty, are wowed by it.“It is testament not only to the hard work of staff and management here at the port, but to that of the skippers, buyers, agents, processors and transportation companies who make the market tick.” vw, px"  However, Simon said with quotas possibly changing next year and the uncertainty of Brexit it was unknown what is in store for next year.He said: “It looks like we might see reduced quotas to deal with next year but discussions are currently ongoing with Norway and Brussels.“At the momentwe can do the same business as last year we’ll still be growing with the new market.”The final market of the year took place on December  with the first of  taking place tomorrow.

title: weather heres your hogmanay forecast from the met office
story: It looks like its going to be a mainly dry night for the tens of thousands expected to attend Hogmanay celebrations across the north-east.Here#s what the Met Office is forecasting for Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire today, tonight and tomorrow.Mostly dry and often cloudy although a few bright spells are likely in the east, perhaps a few sunny intervals. Perhaps some patchy light rain in west. Mild. Strengthening west or southwest winds, with gales later along the Moray Coast. title: work on new drive thru at north east retail park to get underway1
story: Work on a two-storey drive-thru restaurant in a north-east town will begin early next year.Fast food giant McDonald’s is set to build the restaurant at Portlethen Retail Park.The outlet was given approval by Aberdeenshire Council in June after plans were submitted.The proposals are part of an application that would see a six-pump petrol station and click-and-collect lockers on the site.Asda finished an upgrade to its petrol station after a three-month closure in July but work has yet to start on the fast food restaurant.Drivers faced extra miles to fill up their tanks as the petrol station build went on, but the chairman of the Portlethen and district community council Ron Sharp said the time passed without incident.Mr Sharp said: “I thought work would have started on the McDonald’s by now.“Originally I believe they said work would be finished by the end of the year but with the petrol station work it has obviously not happened yet.“There are mixed feelings about this in the community.“There are concerns about litter and the noise it could cause at night with a lot of teenagers potentially hanging about.“However, we do have people who like the idea of having this type of restaurant available on our doorstep. At the moment we will have to suck it up and see what happens.”A spokeswoman for McDonald’s said: “Work will start early .”A number of objections were submitted to Aberdeenshire Council when the plans were first unveiled.The nearby Matalan store has said the McDonald’s restaurant would make the gull problem worse.The area is currently served by a number of food establishments including Domino’s, Ashvale and Subway.Mr Sharp added: “We have had assurances that McDonald’s is a business that looks after litter concerns and they send out their own teams to pick up and sort out any mess.“I do think the McDonald’s will be a welcome job boost in the area, especially with Homebase closing in Portlethen.”

story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ditched doonfoot underpass plans been
story: NewsDitched Doonfoot underpass plans have been resurrectedSouth Ayrshire ruling councillors in the SNP and Labour rejected a plan to build an underpass at Doonfoot in Ayr.ShareBySarah Hilley:,  DEC NewsSNP Councillor Siobhian Brown defied her party to turn against their decision and call it in "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA ditched underpass bid has been resurrected after councillors voted for it to be brought back on the agenda. South Ayrshire ruling councillors in the SNP and Labour rejected a plan to build an underpass at Doonfoot in Ayr. But SNP Councillor Siobhian Brown defied her party to turn against their decision and call it in. In front of a packed council chamber, the Doonfoot politician spoke out against the Leadership Panel vote to install a Toucan crossing instead. She said: “Public safety is at stake here. I urge the  to send this back to the Leadership Panel.” Speaking at the Audit and Governance Panel,she said: “I oppose the amendment on the strongest terms.” A police officer at the meeting backed her up saying the crossing and a mph zone extension would be unsafe. Citing a speeding concern, the police recommended an underpass as well. The Ayrshire Roads Allianceis also in favour of the underground crossing.  ARA head Stewart Turner said: “The best option is the underpass.” During a leadership  meeting last month, Councillor Ian Cochrane put forward an amendment for the crossing and mph extension. It deviated roads department recommendations to get planning consent for the subway this financial year. As a result external funding, which was available for the underpass, would go unused. Tory Councillor Hugh Hunter questioned SNP Councillor Cochrane on why he made the amendment. Councillor Cochrane said he had meant the Toucan crossing to be installed quickly while plans were being made to progress the underpass. The meeting heard how the Leadership Panel minutes did not reflect that. Councillor Hunter said: “The only thing we can do is send this back to the Leadership Panel.” Speaking after the meeting, he added: “There is utter confusion in the Leadership Panel. I was astonished at that. It is a no brainer. What possessed people in a position of leadership to reject advice from the police and the roads department. It beggars belief. They turned down half a million pounds of external funding. There would be no defencesomeone died at that crossing.”  The Panel agreed to send it back to Leadership. Dozens of people donned visitor passes to pack into County Hall for the debate. Keen cyclist Clive Drummond said: “We are pleased that the council have directed the Leadership Panel to reconsider their decision to install a controlled crossing instead of an underpass at Dunure Road, Doonfoot.” He thanked people for firing off  emails to councillors to voice support for the underpass. He also thanked the Ayrshire Roads Alliance, Police Scotland and Councillor Siobhian Brown. Clive, of the South Ayrshire Paths Initiative , added: “SAPI hope the Leadership Panel will avoid further delay and move forward with construction of the underpass, which we believe is the only safe option to link the increasingly popular cycle paths.” He said the end result will be a “safe, easy to use, pleasant five mile walking and cycling route between Alloway and Ayr harbour. The issue was set to be brought back in front of the Leadership Panel yesterday .

title: festering medical waste allowed stack
story: NewsFestering medical waste allowed to stack up at Crosshouse Hospital in KilmarnockYoung interns with additional support needs were asked to deal with the waste that also affects Ayrshire and Ailsa HospitalsShareByFraser N Wilson:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsMedical waste issue at NHS Ayrshire and Arran"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPiles of festering clinical waste is being dumped in locker rooms, car parks and storage areas across NHS Ayrshire and Arran sites say a leading union. And the health board have been asking young interns with additional support needs, and no training, to deal with the problem. Pictures seen by the Standard show dozens of ‘sharps’ boxes filled with hypodermic needles stacked up in full view of the public at a number of sites.  They also show hundreds of rubbish bags bursting from containers with incontinence pads, fluid bags, and materials soaked in blood and other bodily fluids not securely contained. That’s despite medical waste having to be dealt with under the strictest of safety and hygiene conditions. Now Chief Executive John Burns has been forced to issue reassurances to staff and the public, saying the problem had been “addressed immediately”.The Standard can exclusively reveal the extent of the problem faced by waste management operatives on a daily basis, with unions raising “grave concerns” at their exposure to a number of serious health risks. A dossier of evidence submitted to health bosses from UNISON showed project SEARCH interns had been tasked with dealing with the specialist problem. The project helps those aged  to  with additional needs – including those on the autistic spectrum – gain work experience and placements. In his submissions to senior management, Robert Rae, UNISON regional organiser, said the youngsters had been “primarily placed” to deal with disposal tasks. Mr Rae added: “We are calling upon John Burns to take immediate action to address the serious concerns we have with regards the potential risk to safety and wellbeing of staff and patients within NHS Ayrshire and Arran.  “Our members and the patients they serve should not be exposed to any potential risk of infection or injury due to the shambolic way the current waste crisis throughout the UK has been dealt with in NHS Ayrshire and Arran this past week.” Images show orange and yellow bags marked ‘clinical waste for alternative treatment or incineration’ overflowing from container cages at Crosshouse, Ayr and Ailsa hospitals. Another shows ‘sharps’ boxes piled up on top of an industrial freezer next to staff lockers. Cages containing ‘sharps’ boxes, cytotoxic, and used drug vials with the remnants of drugs, can be seen next to a perimeter fence with high banking, meaning anyone could lean over and access the boxes. Glass drugs vials, blood, incontinence pads, and other medical waste can also be seen on the ground.UNISON have raised concerns with the training, protocols, and risk assessments being applied to the disposal and handling of waste. Their report says that bags are being ‘inappropriately handled, stored and transported,’ citing instances where they have been thrown into cages or onto the ground, where they “cannot possibly only be handled by the neck” – the agreed safe method of handling such medical waste. Complaints to health bosses also show “blood spillages are often left untreated all day, despite being seen by supervisors”. Mr Rae added: “A supervisor was unable to advise of the procedure or cleaning agents used to clean this. “It is also concerning that the supervisor himself, when questioned, was unable to provide information on how spillages should be dealt with. “Staff have not been informed nor advised that they should be changing out of their work clothes which are clearly being exposed to spillages and they are travelling home in this clothing. Why have showering, changing, and laundering facilities not been provided in the interim ”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnCrosshouse HospitalAyrKilmarnockAutismDrugsNHS ScotlandEast Ayrshire CouncilPolice ScotlandIndy ref Health and pensionsScottish Government

title: community-rallies-to-support-the-family-of-amanda-cox
story: A HUGE community effort to support the family of Amanda Cox will continue this evening.The -year-old health worker from Peebles tragically died last week at Edinburgh Royal Infirmary, just four days after prematurely giving birth to son, Murray.Amandas husband, Michael, and her wider family were left devastated.But friends have rallied round with emotional and financial support.Since Amandas death a fundraising page, set up by family friend John Clarkson, has raised almost pound, to cover the funeral costs as well as provide ongoing support for Michael as he travels daily to be with his new-born son in hospital.John admits everyone has been overwhelmed by the level of generosity shown.He told us: "I started the fundraising page just to help a mate out."The cost of raising a child can be tough with two wages coming in and now itrsquos just Michaels wage."Now with everything  that he has to think about I just wanted to try and take a tiny bit of a weight off him."I thought setting this up I could maybe raise two or three thousand to help out with Amandarsquos funeral, or for anything he needed it for."Irsquom absolutely stunned and delighted it was so well received by local people and beyond."The gofundme page raised more than the pound, target within the first  hours of being set up.And throughout the weekend and into this week donations have continued to flow in for the grieving family.A special fundraiser will also be held in Michaels hometown of Innerleithen this evening.Staff at the St Ronans Hotel were planning to host a festive disco, but the tragic news of Amandas death pulled the night in a dferent direction.Paul Morgan of the St Ronans Hotel explained: "Two of our regulars who worked alongside Amanda at Haylodge Health Centre were in on Sunday."We were chatting about the fundraising page set up by John Clarkson, which has raised a phenomenal amount of money to help support Michael and his son Murray."The idea for this event came about as there were some unclaimed raffle prizes from the Lights Switch On, so we decided to re-raffle them and put funds towards supporting Amandas family."But it has grown massively this week. The response from businesses in Peebles and Innerleithen has been incredible."We have received over  donations and prizes are still rolling in."The communities have really come together to do what they can to support the family at this sad time. I cannot thank people enough for their generosity."The fundraising event, which will include two raffles and an auction, will take place in St Ronans Hotel tonightfrom pm.Raffle tickets can be purchased directly from the hotel and the Top Stop Coffee Shop.

title: public-consultation-to-be-held-on-booze-ban-plans
story: COUNCIL chiefs have agreed to carry out a new public consultation on its proposed alcohol by-laws.The local authorityrsquos proposals involve setting up designated zones where people can be fined for public drinking in the town centres of Coldingham, Eyemouth, Galashiels, Hawick, Jedburgh, and Newtown St Boswells.People found drinking within the town centre areas could be fined up to pound, but the by-laws will not apply on common riding days and on Hogmanay.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday, councillors were presented with a report by SBCrsquos chief legal officer Nuala McKinley, who explained that other public bodies are in favour of the proposals.She said: ldquoNHS Borders and Police Scotland continue to support the introduction of by-laws.ldquoPolice Scotland had previously expressed their support of the by-laws with a view to reducing public disorder generally in the Scottish Borders area.ldquoNHS Borders are of the view that there are signicant public health benefits in their introduction and the most effective way to reduce alcohol consumption and alcohol related harm is through the availability of alcohol which includes reducing exposure.ldquoStopping street drinking will contribute to this and to protecting vulnerable iniduals and promoting safer communities.ldquoBoth bodies remain of the opinion that by-laws would be a useful tool to assist and support other resources available.However, the majority of councillors felt that because the by-laws were first proposed in , the public consultation carried out around that period was now out of date.In particular, community councils which previously supported the proposals, such as Jedburgh Community Council and Coldingham Community Council, have now withdrawn their support.Speaking in support of more consultation, Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell said: ldquoI think we should start a new consultation.ldquoI donrsquot think we can stop this process, as this was agreed previously by the council, and it would be undemocratic to do so.ldquoI also donrsquot think we can stop it now because we should be an evidence based council and we havenrsquot heard any evidence either in support of this or against it, so we need further consultation and evidence.ldquoI think there is a balance between personal liberty and civic responsibility that needs careful consideration.Hawick and Hermitage councillor David Paterson also spoke in favour of further public consultation: ldquoItrsquos been four or five years since we consulted the public. Irsquom all for what is being proposed but in the interest of fairness we need to go back to the public on this.However, some councillors have spoked out in opposition to introducing any anti-alcohol by-laws at all.In particular, Jedburgh and District councillor Scott Hamilton said the by-laws would contravene personal liberties, and tabled a motion calling for the proposals to be scrapped altogether.He told fellow councillors: ldquoBy agreeing to move these by-laws forward, we will be starting a process which barbarously pushes back our freedoms and personal liberties.ldquoIt is the freedom of choice which has underpinned the very ethos of le in the western world, and we this morning seek to change a liberty. Granted, it is a small liberty, but it must be treated with utmost care and consideration.ldquoWe need to have a real and considered debate before deciding on this. One of the endearing things about the Europeans, and I say this as a Brexiteer, is their cafe culture. This type of activity would be forbidden in places like Jedburgh.ldquoWhen a family goes to the park for a picnic, and brings a bottle of wine, they are now caught in the battle between over-legislation and common sense.ldquoI would say letrsquos encourage cafe lestyle, and its economic potential for increasing footfall and destination desirability.Although councillor Hamiltonrsquos motion was defeated by  votes to seven, councillors decided not to submit their by-laws to the Scottish Government and instead opted for more research into the potential benefits and disadvantages and for further public consultation.

title: council-accused-of-paying-over-the-odds-for-lowood-estate
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has been told ldquoit may come to regret its decision to buy what remains of the Lowood Estate after it was revealed that government valuers advised the authority it would be paying over the odds.The council has spent pound.m on purchasing land to the south of the River Tweed with a view to building hundreds of houses and an industrial estate there.Council officers believe that the site, as part of a wider Tweedbank development plan, will create  permanent jobs, and a similar number during the construction phase.The site has also been earmarked for a -home housing estate.At a full meeting of the council yesterday, December , its executive member for business and economic development, Mid-Berwickshire councillor Mark Rowley, told members: ldquoThis was a project set in motion by a previous council.ldquoIn , the previous council agreed to the purchase of Lowood in principle, and over the last few years, work has been developing on this.ldquoWhat makes this incredibly important, probably more important than it was in , is that with all the talk around budgets, the council can no longer just sit back and try to carry on carrying out services.ldquoWe need to take decisive and strategic action, and this is an incredibly bold, and good, large-scale development.ldquoItrsquos maximising benefits wersquore already seeing with the Borders Railway. It strengthens the case, very strongly, for extending the railway to Carlisle, so I am incredibly supportive, as yoursquod expect. I think this helps us grow the Borders on to success.ldquoThe stats sound almost academic and meaningless, but wersquore talking about a development here of hundreds of jobs.ldquoThat is a huge leap for the Borders, especially when these better, higher-paid jobs come in. It gives us a business space of a quality which we donrsquot currently have in the Borders, and it gives us control over a potentially fantastic housing site.ldquoThis is positive and a good news story.Council officers estimate that developing the estate would cost an extra poundm on top of the price of the land but would potentially generate poundm of gross value added for the regionrsquos economy.However, Tweeddale East councillor and opposition leader Stuart Bell claims the estate is valued at much less than the council paid for it.Mr Bell also revealed that Scottish Governmentrsquos district valuation service, a body offering impartial advice on how public money is spent, also told the council the property was not worth what it has paid for it.He told members: ldquoThe Lowood Estate acquisition, which we are undertaking by ourselves, remains a tortured tale.ldquoThe pound.m outlay, plus expenses, plus cost of maintaining the land and assets, plus the cost of borrowing, means wersquoll need to sell it all for over poundm just to break even. ldquoReports we have seen in private say there will also be signicant infrastructure costs to develop the site.ldquoI donrsquot believe this site is worth pound.m when you go into the detail of the terms and conditions of the sale, and that was the opinion of the district valuer, whose assessment with vacant possession, which we will not have, was much lower than pound.m.ldquoEven when adjusted up for a special assumption, the district valuer still valued the land at a price lower than we are paying.ldquoThis is a speculative and risky expenditure of public money at a time when, quite apart from Brexit, there is shuddering uncertainty in markets. ldquoHouse prices and land values can go down as well as up. We should not be spending public money on buying this estate at this time for more than it is worth.ldquoIn what alternative opportunities could we invest poundm ldquoThis council should invest enough in roads to signicantly improve the road condition index, but we cannot afford to do that.ldquoThis council should commit to four new high schools in  years, but you wonrsquot make that commitment.ldquoI will not tell the electors in Peebles, as you will have to, that they cannot have a new high school within  years when you have tied up poundm for  or so years in Tweedbank.ldquoWe canrsquot even cut the grass properly in our cemeteries, but this administration glibly spends poundm on buying a private estate.ldquoThis is a decision I fear you may come to regret.In reply, East Berwickshire councillor Jim Fullarton defended the deal, claiming that pressures on local government spending made such projects necessary, saying: ldquoWersquove had several briefings on this subject, and officers have presented us with an excellent paper on the future benefits of developing this site, especially with the council in control.ldquoNow councillor Bell is scaremongering about service cuts, but this is a smokescreen to keep us away from the real issue at hand, which is the financial pressure being passed down to Scottish local authorities by his SNP colleagues.ldquoScottish local councils are currently expected to continue services while facing continuous cuts.ldquoIt will be very interesting to see what opposition councillors bring to the table for their budget proposals. No doubt there will be some vanity projects.The Tweedbank masterplan, going hand in hand with the Borders Railway blueprint programme, includes earmarking residential and business space on the estate, as well as expanding Tweedbank and rebranding the current industrial estate there as the Borders Innovation Park.The deal agreed with the estatersquos owner, Alexander Hamilton, is for the remaining  acres still in private hands to add to the  acres bought from then owner Constance Hamilton using compulsory powers by the former Roxburgh County Council in the early s to create Tweedbank.The land will now be owned by Lowood Tweedbank, a company set up and owned by the council.

title: royal-scots-history-is-on-parade-at-peebles-library
story: AN historic link between Peebles and what was Britains oldest infantry regiment was further strengthened this week with a presentation at the towns library.The Royal Scots was raised by Royal Warrant in  and subsequently served with distinction for almost four centuries through many campaigns across the globe.The Regiment continued to recruit almost entirely from Edinburgh, the Lothians and Peeblesshire until its amalgamation just over a decade ago.During the First World War the Regiment expanded to  battalions in which over , men served.During the - conflict a total of , Royal Scots made the ultimate sacrice - many from the Borders, including  from Peebles,  from Innerleithen and  from Walkerburn.The Royal Scots served in most of the campaigns of the First World War, from the Western Front to Bulgaria.To mark the close connection with the area the Regiment was awarded the Freedom of Peebles in .As the centenary year of World War I ending draws to a close this month, a presentation was made on Tuesday by representatives of The Royal Scots Association at Peebles Library.Nick Edwardson and Alex Dockar presented a rare three-volume History of the Royal Scotsto head librarian Alison Tait.Mr Edwardson told us: "The presentation of the volumes acknowledges the contribution made by the county of Peeblesshire to the story of Britainrsquos senior infantry regiment."The Regiment was amalgamated in  but its long history of proud service continues today as part of st Battalion The Royal Regiment of Scotland.The Colours of the Regimentrsquos th Battalion which historically had a particular association with Peebles were laid up in the town in .And they are now displayed outside the entrance to the library in the Chambers Institute.The three-volume History of the Royal Scots will now be available for everyone to read in the library.

title: chance-for-parents-to-register-children-for-nursery-places
story: PARENTS in the Borders are being invited to register their children for a place at nursery.Enrolment week takes place from Monday, January , to Friday, January . And locals with children born between March , , and February , , will be able to visit the nursery of their choice to fill in an application form.Parents will have to provide their childrsquos birth certicate and proof of address. As it is not always possible for children to be given the setting of their first choice, they will also be asked to provide an alternative.Councillor Carol Hamilton, SBCrsquos executive member for children and young people, said: ldquoWe would ask all parents and carers of eligible children to register with their preferred setting during enrolment week and make sure that their child has a place for next yearrsquos session.ldquoThere are a number of benefits to taking up these funded places as the hours help to give children a signicant start to their education by encouraging them to learn through play with other children, develop their language and social skills and prepare for school.ldquoThey also give parents time to help them get back to work, study or training and have more flexibility to organise their family le.The Scottish government currently provides all three and four-year-olds with  hours of free early learning and childcare. But the hours are being increased from  to ,.Application packs can also be downloaded from: www.scotborders.gov.uk elc

title: pet-of-the-week
story: This weeks Pet Of The Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, is Bea.The charity told us: "Bea is a beautul six-year-old Corn Snake who came in to us as her owners no longer had the time or space for her."Bea has not had much handling and is a bit shy and grumpy because of this, so would be best suited to an experienced owner who can help her learn to trust people."Bea has been eating well while with us and appears to be a healthy girl, so given the chance were sure she will make a great pet."If you would like to offer Bea her forever home, please call Borders Pet Rescue on   or email info@borderspetrescue.org."

title: get-a-first-glimpse-of-the-new-improved-eastgate
story: PLANS for transforming the Eastgate Theatre are set to go on show.A huge fundraising effort by supporters of the theatre reached the required pound, target for theatre bosses to access further financing streams.And now the ambitious plans to improve the auditorium, as well as future projects, will be revealed during the first weekend of January.Maggie Mackay, marketing manager at the Eastgate, told us: "During both days everyone is invited to visit the theatre where there will be an opportunity to test sample seats, see artist impressions of options to bring the side galleries into full use and talk with representatives from the Project Design Group about these designs, the planned timetable for the work and the ambition to move onto the next development phase - staged improvements to the ground floor foyer and cafeacute areas."The plans will be on display between pm and pm on both Saturday and Sunday, January  and .

title: abbotsford-volunteers-make-new-chapter-success
story: ABBOTSFORD has just entered the record books by becoming the first historic house museum in Scotland to be awarded Volunteer Friendly status.The Abbotsford Trust has just received the Volunteer Friendly Award.Currently  organisations across Scotland hold the award, with  in the Scottish Borders.Assessors scrutinised the charityrsquos policies and procedures in five strands covering a range of areas including training, motivation, equality and communication.Volunteer Centre Borders executive Gordon Brown said: ldquoVolunteers are an integral part of ensuring Sir Walter Scottrsquos legacy at Abbotsford continues and this is obvious from their work plans and how they are supported in their volunteering roles.ldquoAt a time when volunteers are needed more than ever before, good volunteer management is essential and it is obvious The Abbotsford Trust puts volunteering at the forefront of its strategic planning.In  Abbotsford secured three-year funding from Historic Environment Scotland to invest in volunteers, enabling the appointment of a Volunteer Coordinator and the introduction of a volunteer training programme.Since then the number of volunteers has grown from  to , with new roles of path wardens, event volunteers and minibus drivers joining the existing guides, room stewards, gardeners and visitor centre volunteers.Giles Ingram, Chief Executive of Abbotsford, said: ldquoAs an independent charity, the Abbotsford Trust relies heavily on the support and goodwill of our army of volunteers."Their enthusiasm and generosity of time is invaluable and we really appreciate all they do across the estate.To show its appreciation of the army of volunteers, the Trust hosts regular social events, including a quiz night, Christmas lunch and outings to other historic visitor attractions.There are also regular meetings and an annual survey to keep up-to-date with the support volunteers need.At this yearrsquos Christmas lunch,  volunteers who have served with Abbotsford since the house reopened in July  received five-year long-service awards, to mark their commitment.Claudia Bolling, volunteer co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am always telling the volunteers that we really couldnrsquot do what we do without them, and it is so true."They delivered more than , hours of service in the  months until September , which is invaluable to a charity like Abbotsford.ldquoWe were delighted that in our last survey  percent of those who responded said they would recommend volunteering at Abbotsford to their family and friends.Anyone interested in becoming a volunteer at Abbotsford can find out more at the next annual recruitment day on January .

title: country-music-show-is-returning-to-the-borders
story: A PEEBLES audience will be taken to Nashville and back in one night next month.Locals will be able to enjoy the hits of the likes of Patsy Cline and Johnny Cash when the Legends of American Country Showmakes itsto the Eastgate Theatre.A promoter for the event told us: ldquoNow seen by over , fans, the hugely popular hit show is set to make its welcome Peebles .ldquoAnd what a night of toe tapping country music itrsquos going to be.ldquoThe show is enjoying huge success this year with over  sold out shows at prestigious theatres all across the UK. It features four fantastic singers Joe Moore, James Mc Garrity, and Rod and Tracey McAuley who perform the hit songs of icons like Johnny Cash, Dolly Parton, Kenny Rogers, Patsy Cline and Don Williams to name a few in this two-hour country extravaganza that will take you to Nashville and back in one night.The event will take place on Wednesday, January , at the Eastgate Theatre at .pm.Ticketscost pound and are available from the Eastgate Theatre box office on  or online at www.eastgatearts

title: borders-top-cop-is-set-to-retire
story: POLICE Scotlands Area Commander for the Borders, Andy McLean, is about to retire.Having joined Lothian and Borders Police in Galashiels in , Chief Inspector McLean has served in ious unorm roles over the past three decades.In his tenure, he has worked within Response and Community Policing, Road Policing and Public Order roles.Speaking ahead of his retirement Andy told us: "It has been my absolute honour and privilege to have worked for this organisation, and for Lothian and Borders Police beforehand."Putting on the unorm always gave me a tremendous sense of pride and while it will be strange to no longer do this each day, I am looking forward to the next chapter and what it will involve."While Ive enjoyed all of my roles, being able to serve as Local Area Commander for the Borders is undoubtedly a career highlight and I am extremely grateful to all of the officers and staff Ive worked with and who have helped make our area such a wonderful place to live."Id also like to extend my sincerest thanks to the ious partner organisations, whom we work closely with on a daily basis. Your support of our campaigns, operations and policing plans have been pivotal to the successes we have achieved."Chief Inspector Stuart Reid has been appointed as the new Local Area Commander.And he will officially take over on Friday, December .Chief Inspector Reid has  years of service in both CID and Response Policing at all ranks from PC DC to DCI CI as well as Emergency Planning.Ahead of beginning his new role, Chief Inspector Reid said: "The Scottish Borders is not only one of the most scenic and erse regions to work in, but one of the most demanding and I relish this new opportunity."Throughout the region, the needs of specic communities y greatly, from rural issues, to drug crime and road policing matters."I plan to build on the outstanding success of my predecessor and ensure that our policing approach reflects these very dferent requirements, so we best serve all of those who live and work within the Borders."It is also my intention to continue our close working relationship with our partner agencies and develop new initiatives, which can see us work together to improve the quality of le for our communities."I cannot wait to get started and am really looking forward to meeting the officers, staff, partners, elected members and general public for this amazing region."

title: unpaid-work-for-st-boswells-flat-wrecker
story: A NEWTOWN St Boswells man who admitted damaging a flat during a drinking session has been ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work at Selkirk Sherf Court.Kevin Grieve pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner at Sprouston Cottages, St Boswells, on August  by shouting and swearing, throwing items around the flat and knocking over furniture.He also admitted a second charge of wilfully and recklessly throwing plants out of pots.The court heard that the -year-old of Eildon Terrace, Newtown St Boswells, had been invited to the property for a drink.The householder left at around .pm leaving Grieve and another person who he became abusive towards.Defence Ed Hulme said his client had no recollection of the events.In addition to the unpaid work, Grieve was ordered to pay pound in compensation to Scottish Borders Housing Association for the damage to the property.

title: staff-raise-1200-for-bgh-unit-during-christmas-party
story: STAFF at a luxury spa have raised more than pound for charity at their Christmas Party.Stobo Castles workforce held a staff raffle to provide funds for the Margaret Kerr Unit at Borders General Hospital.And they raised an amazing pound for the regions only palliative care unit.Stobo marketing director Jenni Watts told us: "The team at Stobo were only too happy to dig deep at their recent staff Christmas party and raised over pound for a charity close to all their hearts, the Margaret Kerr Unit at Borders General Hospital."Some fantastic raffle prizes were up for grabs and Stobo Castle would like to thank all businesses who donated."

title: frankies-golden-locks-are-donated-for-christmas
story: A KIND-HEARTED Tweedbank girl has sacriced her flowing locks this Christmas for charity.Frankie Harkness wanted to do her bit for cancer charities after being moved by a television advert.And the seven-year-old, who is a pupil at St Peterrsquos in Galashiels, decided to donate her long blonde hair to the wig-making Little Princess Trust.Frankie has also raised almost pound for the organisation which supplies hundreds of wigs every year to children and young adults who have lost their hair during cancer treatments.On the Friday before Christmas Frankie had around  inches of hair chopped off at The Style Station in Tweedbank.Mum Jenner told us: ldquoThis was all Frankiersquos idea.ldquoAfter seeing the cancer advert on TV she asked how she could help.ldquoThe Little Princess Trust do such wonderful work and Irsquom so proud of Frankie for donating almost all of her hair.The Little Princess Trust was founded just over a decade ago by the parents of Hannah Tarplee.The youngster, who eventually lost her battle with cancer, had enjoyed wearing a wig made from real hair during her treatment.And the Trust in her memory has allowed thousands of others in a similar situation to also have specialist real-hair wigs.Fridayrsquos big chop was the first time Frankiersquos hair had been cut for over two years.But after going under the scissors, the primary three pupil was happy with the new-look bob she will be sporting over Christmas.She said: ldquoI was scared to look at first but I quite like it.The Style Station in Tweedbank donated the cost of the hair cut to Frankiersquos fundraising page.Stylist Hannah Falconer said: ldquoI did a similar hair cut for a friend of my mum to give to the same charity but this is the first time wersquove had a little girl in to have her long hair cut off.ldquoIt takes a lot of courage to have all of your hair cut off ndash so well done Frankie.As well as donating her hair Frankie is also raising money to help the same charity manufacture the real-hair wigs.And so far she has raised almost pound.To make a donation go to https:www.justgiving fundraising jen-harkness

title: cold-comforts-a-qa-with-peebles-film-festival-star-calum-maclean
story: BASED in the Highlands, Calum Maclean is a filmmaker, TV presenter and obsessive outdoor swimmer who routinely seeks out wild ndash and usually freezing ndash stretches of water in which to get his next swim fix. Ahead of his appearance at the Peebles Outdoor Film Festival in January, Rich Rowe from the Eastgate Theatre caught up with Calum to find out more...Q. What do you love most about swimming outside A. The guaranteed buzz. Cold water can leave you on quite a high ndash you feel like yoursquove achieved something, even after a short dip.Q. Whenwas your first swim outdoors A. It must have been in the Isle of Skye, possibly off the small skerries in Loch Eishort.Q. Sea, loch, or river hellip or does it not matter A. I love all three, and my favourite is usually the one Irsquove been away from for too long. Irsquom currently missing long sea swims, which I hope to get back to.Q. Swim shorts or budgie smugglers A. Swim shorts .Q. At what point do you reach for a wetsuit A. Irsquoll swim anything without a wetsuit hellipjust not for long. Even in summer Irsquoll usually wear the wetsuit for longer distances ndash anything more than  minutes-ish.Q. Does the thought of swimming in a heated indoor pool fill you with terror A. When I dream, itrsquos of open water ndash my nightmares involve turning at the end of a . In all honesty, Irsquove grown to enjoy pools, but only because I know itrsquoll make me a better outdoor swimmer. But I refuse to learn tumble-turns.Q. A Gaelic speaker, you recently presented a series about wild swimming for BBC Alba. What was that like A, Hard work. For some reason, it was decided Dhan Uisgeshould be filmed in winter. Great, but filming TV usually involves two three takes of the same shot to cover the action hellip so,  minutes in ice-bound Lochindorb ndash but I still loved it. Itrsquos a privilege to do what you love and share that with people.Q. Whatrsquos the most challenging stretch of water yoursquove taken a dip in A. It would have to be at Sanna Bay, Ardnamurchan. It was quite a choppy day with strong currents and we were filming for Dhan Uisge. As I did a piece to camera from the sea, the current almost whipped us out and around a skerry.Q. You have a love of searching out new swim spots. Any recently discovered gems A. Feshiebridge in the Cairngorms has a couple of beautul, clear pools just by the road, butyou mountain bike upstream for about an hour or so, therersquos a deep, dark waterfall pool to cool off in.Q. Have you ever swum in the River Tweed  If not, we can recommend a few spots.A. Never ndash Irsquom very excited for my first ever swim in the River Tweed and anywhere  exciting nearby, suggestions welcome.Q. We canrsquot wait to have you with us in Peebles. What can audiences expect A. Stories of swimming, irreverence and some laughs. Irsquoll give my take on outdoor swimming, places Irsquove been and the question that always follows outdoor swimmers: why  Itrsquos a night for anyone who has an interest in the Scottish outdoors, outdoor swimming and never taking themselves too seriously.An ambassador for The Outdoor Swimming Society, Calum Maclean is one of the headline speakers at the  Peebles Outdoor Film Festival, held at the Eastgate Theatre, from January -.See him in the Cold Comforts session, at .pm on Saturday, January . Ticketsavailable from the box office on  , or online at www.eastgatearts
